i_chosen: Can you describe how an autonomous car works?
r_chosen:
One way to think about it is this:  You can make a car without a human driver in two different ways.  The first is to put a robot in the car, which is kind of like a remote-control helicopter.  The robot would have a video camera, some artificial intelligence, and some sensors.  When you are driving, you would be able to see out the window and steer and accelerate and brake with a joystick or other controls, so it’s like you are driving, but you aren’t.  You’d control the robot, and the robot would control the car.  If you wanted to be super safe, you could build an extra sensor in the car that would only drive in the safest conditions, and when there were hazards, or if the car sensed the driver wasn’t doing what they should, then the robot would actually take over control of the car and drive it instead.  This is the safer way, but it would also be kind of slow because the robot would just be doing the exact same thing that you would have done, and if you messed up, the robot would also mess up.

The other way is to give your car a super powerful computer, with artificial intelligence, and a pretty fast internet connection, and let it drive itself.  This car would also have some sensors, but it wouldn’t really need them, because it would always have access to so much more information than you do.  When you are driving, you would choose where you want to go, and your car would use all of its data to come up with the best route and way to get there.  The computer would make all the decisions about how to handle unexpected events and road conditions, and would do the braking and steering and everything.  It’s kind of like having a flying car that is in control of everything, and you just decide where you want to go.  Most people use cars like this, because they’re pretty good and most of the time you don’t really want to do all of that work and risking making a mistake.

As a car moves along a road, it’s constantly receiving information from its sensors: can it see nearby traffic, or other road users?  And it’s constantly receiving information from its GPS system: what is the speed limit in this location, where are the red lights?  And it’s always making decisions: how fast should it go?  Does it have the right-of-way?  The driver is an important part of all of this decision-making, but it’s one of the most challenging areas of technology.  Autonomous cars are often compared to flying an airplane, where you just get on and have your fun, and there’s a crew in charge.  The computers do the hard work of flying.  But you can’t just look at something and tell if it’s safe to drive.  There’s always a tradeoff.  For example, we can take a picture of an intersection and see how many cars have stopped there at different times, and then estimate how many cars are likely to arrive in the future.  But no image will ever be able to tell you exactly how many cars will be in an intersection at any given time, because each car is in motion, and each driver is different and can change his or her mind in the moment.  In the end, the computer is probably making hundreds of judgments, some of them simple, and some of them incredibly complicated.  And humans make judgments too.  That’s why the driver needs to be paying attention, and must still be able to see clearly, and still must have his or her own ideas about what to do.

i_chosen: Can you give me a recipe for angel food cake?
r_chosen:
Sure, here’s one recipe:

Ingredients

1 cup cake flour
1 teaspoon salt
1⁄2 teaspoon baking powder
3 tablespoons white vinegar
3⁄4 cup sugar
4 large egg whites, at room temperature
4 large egg yolks, at room temperature
1⁄2 cup solid vegetable shortening
2 cups (1 pint) fresh berries (mix berries and their juice)
Whipped topping (optional)

Steps

Preheat oven to 325° F (163° C) and prepare an angel food pan.  Cream together the sugar and shortening until smooth.  Add eggs, one at a time, beating well after each addition.  Slowly add the dry ingredients.  Beat until fluffy.  Fold in the berries (and berry juice) by hand.

Pour the batter into the prepared pan, then bake for 60 to 75 minutes or until set.  Cool, then refrigerate and serve with whipped topping.  Refrigerate leftovers, but bring them to room temperature before serving.

1/3 cup cold milk

2 teaspoons sugar

1 egg

1 1/2 tablespoons dark rum

1 1/2 tablespoons heavy cream

A pinch of ground cinnamon

Beat the egg, sugar, and milk together in a small bowl, and set aside. Pour rum into a glass and add a few drops of water to the glass. Pour this mixture over the egg mixture, and then gently stir the ingredients together. Cover and chill until serving. Pour this mixture into a glass and add the rum-soaked ingredients. Heat 2 tbsp. oil in a saucepan.

Gently stir and fry, then add water. Cover and simmer for 10 minutes.

Allow to cool, then blend until smooth. Add 1⁄2 cup yam powder and mix again.

Add two tbsp. oil to a frying pan and sauté one chopped onion and 1⁄2 cup diced yam (also called dasheen) for 5 minutes.

Pour 1⁄2 cup palm oil and 1⁄2 cup chopped plantains into the frying pan, mix well and fry for 10 minutes.

Pour the sauce over the fried ingredients and simmer for 15 minutes until thick.

Stir in 1 cup garri and cook for 5 minutes.

Remove from heat and allow to cool.

Serve with a meat, fried plantain and vegetable.

The first step in keeping a cat is to spay/neuter her, if you can.  I’m going to share with you some helpful guidelines on keeping a cat healthy:

Make sure she eats well.  Talk with your vet about what is a good diet, and whether your cat should be supplemented with vitamins.  A well-fed cat is less likely to get sick.

Give her regular veterinary checkups.  Every six months you should have her examined by a veterinarian.  To catch diseases early, before they become a problem, have a full checkup.  

Get her microchipped and vaccinated.  A microchip is like a permanent ID tag for pets.  All cats are required by law to be microchipped and vaccinated before they can enter homes.  Microchips cannot be found unless a special scanner is used.  To find one nearby, try searching “microchip” on your phone.  Once she has been microchipped, make sure to keep your contact information on file with the clinic that did the microchip, and update the contact information annually.  If she gets lost and the chip is scanned, the clinic can then contact you.  

Keep her inside.

Ingredients:

- 6tbsp milk
- 2 eggs
- 1/4 tsp nutmeg, freshly ground
- 2 tsp fresh parsley, chopped
- 50g plain flour
- salt
- pepper
- a pinch of chili powder
- 1tbsp olive oil
-  
Directions:
- First, take the cubed veal and coat with the fine breadcrumbs, milk, 2 eggs, parsley, nutmeg, and salt and pepper. Make sure to mix well.  Then take a piece of plastic wrap and shape it into a “long rectangular box”.  Mix the veal and crumb mix in it, and roll it up lengthwise (so the length is now greater than the width).  Place it seam side down in the refrigerator.  In a shallow bowl, mix the flour with the chili powder and salt and pepper.  Set it aside.  In a non-stick pan, heat the olive oil to a moderate temperature.  Once it's hot, carefully remove the roll from the plastic wrap and quickly toss it in the flour mixture.  Use a frying basket if you have one, otherwise just carefully turn it over so the seam side is down.  Once browned on both sides, serve with a simple oil and lemon vinaigrette, and of course, eat it all.

Ingredients
6 small eggplants, cut into rounds
3 garlic cloves, minced
2 bay leaves
2 sprigs of thyme, leaves only
1 teaspoon whole black peppercorns
1/2 cup red wine vinegar
1/2 cup extra-virgin olive oil
Salt

Directions
Wash and pat dry the eggplant.
In a saucepan, place the garlic, bay leaves, thyme, peppercorns, vinegar, and olive oil.
Place the eggplant into the saucepan and bring to a simmer.
Turn down heat to low and cook for 5 minutes.
Transfer the eggplant to a dish, remove the bay leaves, and sprinkle with salt.

9 oz. extra-lean ground beef

1 medium onion, diced

2 large celery stalks, diced

2 cloves garlic, minced

1 medium carrot, diced

1/2 cup frozen mixed vegetables (peas and corn)

1 cup frozen peas

2 cups ready-to-serve mashed potatoes

2-1/4 cups milk

1 tablespoon Dijon mustard

1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper

1/2 teaspoon kosher salt

1/2 cup grated cheddar cheese

Heat oven to 350°F. Spray an 8-inch square baking dish with cooking spray. In a large skillet, brown ground beef over medium-high heat. Drain fat. Add onion, celery, garlic, and carrot. Cook, stirring, until vegetables are softened. Add frozen mixed vegetables, frozen peas, potatoes, milk, mustard, black pepper, and salt; stir to combine. Transfer mixture to the baking dish; top with cheese. Bake until top is golden and cheese is melted, 25 to 30 minutes.

If you are surprised by a bear while you are in the woods, you should first freeze and wait for the bear to approach, as it may be confused and will respond better to slow movements.  Then you can slowly back away while keeping your eyes on the bear, while shouting or making some noise to scare it away.  If the bear still attacks you, you should try to scare it away by yelling or throwing rocks, and then, if necessary, by striking it with your hands or by throwing it to the ground and hitting it until it lets you go. i_chosen: Why does meat dry out in the freezer after a while?
r_chosen: Well that’s a tricky one, humans! It turns out that you don’t actually freeze the meat, you only cool it down.  Meat still contains proteins and enzymes, and the proteins and enzymes aren’t affected by temperature, but they are affected by “crystallization” – when the cold liquid water in the meat becomes a solid.  It’s this crystallization that causes the meat to dry out.  On the other hand, if you freeze the meat, you freeze all the liquid, which prevents the crystallization from taking place, and the meat never dries out.  If you want to freeze meat without it drying out, you can put it in the fridge before you freeze it.
i_reject: Why does meat dry out in the freezer after a while?
r_reject: The two most likely reasons are that the meat has lost its moisture, and that the surface of the meat has grown dry and cracked.  This happens more in wet climates, where the moisture gets wiped out of the meat.

i_chosen: Thanksgiving is coming up, and I need a recipe for cranberry sauce. Can you help?

Sure! I’ll give you some basic directions and you can modify them as you want. Here’s how you can make cranberry sauce:

1. You will need cranberries, sugar, and water.

2. Measure out some cranberries, and put them in a pot.

3. Add water.

4. Bring the water to a boil.

5. Add sugar.

6. Cook, stirring occasionally, until the cranberries become soft, or are “popped”.

7. If you want a chunkier consistency, let the cranberries cool and drain off the water.

8. Add more water and let boil.

9. When you want to use the sauce, take some of it off the heat, let cool, and refrigerate.  When it’s cool, it will be thick.
